TopicTitle: How do I recover launch clamps?

Articles.Content:
Just notice that while sometimes launch clamps remain on the pad, quite often they silently disappear. I wonder why.

I'm not overly concerned about lauch clamps, but I'd like to recover some boosters. If they burn out early enough, that ought to be easy... and indeed I see them land, I can still see them from map view while I'm about to leave the atmosphere, then suddenly they're gone. I don't think I've ever seen them vanish... I think it happens while switching to and from the map.

Those boosters tend to drop on the launchpad, or at least the hexagon that surrounds it. I wonder if the mechanism that spirits them away is the one that's responsible for cleaning up the clamps.
Launch clamps and any other debris landed at KSC is automatically recovered when it leaves the physics range (when you go more than 22.5 km away from it)

> 
> Launch clamps and any other debris landed at KSC is automatically recovered when it leaves the physics range (when you go more than 22.5 km away from it)

Doesn't work for me. I always have to recover my clamps. Luckily it's easy to do so with the KSC view craft pins.

Then again I don't use the typical setup. I'm running 64 bit linux build 1.0.2 on Ubuntu 12.04. Full stock though, or sometimes with Claw's stock bug fixes but never other mods.

I meant "is **sometimes** automatically recovered", it seems to be triggered by something which doesn't always happen. I'm pretty sure launch clamps are automatically recovered without prompt when you launch a new ship though.

Or possibly they removed auto-recovery? It certainly used to be a thing anyway.
And that's why I use stage recovery mod. It'll also tell me how much I recovered them for
Launch clamps are automatically recovered only if there's a scene change to the space center and back.
I'm pretty certain that what I'm experiencing is not auto-recovery. Or at any rate, my bank account doesn't change when the parts disappear.

I've had Stage Recovery installed months ago. never looked back.

I totally recommend it, even if it can be a bit too lenient on you sometimes.
